Real Time CT and CT Fluoroscopy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This white paper is a quick introduction to CT fluoroscopy and its dosimetry issues (doses and how to limit them).

X.T: Multi-slice helical CT physics and technology

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good presentation of the evolution of CT technology.

X.T: CT Update: Slice by Slice

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A snapshot of the CT state of the art: 64 slices, software applications…

X.T: MDCT correlates ACS to mixed plaques

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It seems that acute coronary events are linked to mixed plaques which are mostly noncalcified.

X.T: Dual-source CT overcomes artifacts in coronary imaging

ARTICLE.COMMENT: DSCT enables scan at higher heartbeat rates.

X.T: Fourth-generation MDCT scanners do cardiac differently

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Siemens, Toshiba, GE, and Philips are using different solutions to improve their scanners.

X.T: Three-Dimensional Endoluminal CT Colonography (Virtual Colonoscopy): Comparison of Three Commercially Available Systems

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A comparison of Navigator, Vitrea 2, and V3D-Colon.

X.T: VC gets long-awaited reporting standards

ARTICLE.COMMENT: C-RADS: a proposition for virtual colonoscopy standardized reports.

X.T: 'Filet view' VC software slices reading time

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The advantage of using a projection of the colon on a plane. (Advantage Windows has this for several years… it seems that Philips is still late compared to GE.)

X.T: CT, radiation, and risk: two views

ARTICLE.COMMENT: People disagree about the statitical modelisation of the number of cancers induced by low radiations.

X.T: Full-body screening elevates cancer mortality risk

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another study on radiation impact: 30 full body scans would result in a 2% raise of cancer mortality.

X.T: ACC studies examine CTA radiation dose

ARTICLE.COMMENT: ECG gating enables dose reduction.

X.T: Study shows whole-body CT screening centers on the rise

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all. Do you think these guys who ask for a full body scan really know the impact of XRays?

X.T: Standard-dose no better than low-dose CT for diagnosing appendicitis

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Gonadal shield cuts scatter radiation from MDCT

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using lead capsules greatly reduces the testicular dose. But nobody is doing this…

X.T: Associations set benchmarks for x-ray, CT, fluoro doses

ARTICLE.COMMENT: AAPM and ACR define some advisory radiation limits.

X.T: Radiation dose slashed in 64-slice coronary CTA

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Not using helical mode results in lower dose.

X.T: Parents sue California hospital over pediatric CT radiation overdose

ARTICLE.COMMENT: "The technologist took 151 CT scans [of a 23 months old boy] in a 65-minute period". How is this possible?

X.T: California hospital fined $25,000 for pediatric CT radiation overdose

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The analysis of the child overdose.

X.T: California RT gives deposition in CT overdose case

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The trial is expected in February 2010.

X.T: Nailed in the head: X-ray, CT show patient's good luck

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using CT to count and find the positions of nails in a worker's head…

X.T: Part I: Radiologists prepare for growing CT role in virtual autopsy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the methods used by some forensic departments.

X.T: Innovation notwithstanding, CT has a long wish list

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Willi Kalender would like shorter scan times, higher and configurable spatial resolution, using different spectra and saying that CT generates low doses.

X.T: In high-tech Japan, most CT scanners are still primitive

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The status of the Japan's CT installed base: most scanners are old technology.

X.T: Prototype 256-slice CT scanner creates high-res images in a heartbeat

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Toshiba releases the 256-slices prototype.

X.T: CT pioneer test-drives 256-slice scanner

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some feedback about Toshiba's prototype, but there is nothing new in this article.

X.T: Multislice CT powers up with dual-source scanning

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The advantages of DSCT: scans are faster, so no beta-blockers are needed; subtraction of dual energy images… But this seems to be an advertisement for Siemens.

X.T: Siemens launches Definition Flash as flagship dual-source CT scanner

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Somatom Definition Flash is the new version of Siemens' DSCT: faster, larger scanning field, low-energy photon filtering, and dose reduction.

X.T: GE focuses on high-res CT with launch of LightSpeed CT750 scanner

ARTICLE.COMMENT: For the time being, GE focuses on improving the detector and the tube, rather than continuing the slice war.

X.T: The Heart of MR

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Cardiac MR looks promising, but who will own the market: radiologists or cardiologists?

X.T: MR-guided intervention takes off in Japan

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Dr. Morikawa reports how he is performing MR-guided surgery.

X.T: World's most powerful MRI ready to scan human brain

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The first safety trial with a 9.4T machine.

X.T: Breakthroughs in Imaging Neurovascular Diseases

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After explaining the basis of MRI, E. Mark Haacke describes the new technologies to measure iron concentration. After, he tries to convince Google to help for a very large study to test the hypothesis of a relation between chronic cerebro-spinal venous insufficiency and multiple sclerosis.

X.T: Chilled loop failure: How to break your magnet without even trying

ARTICLE.COMMENT: When the chilled water loop contains rust.

X.T: The fire extinguisher in your MRI suite: will it save a life or take one?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to choose a safe and effective fire extinguishers for a MR room.

X.T: Did the MRI community learn from the Colombini tragedy?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The death of a young boy in a MRI suite has not been a trigger to set up MRI safety rules.

X.T: The new 'MR Safe': Language changes for the FDA

ARTICLE.COMMENT: ASTM International proposes a classification for MR safetiness of objects.

X.T: Magnet room doors and quench entrapment

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The door of the MR room should open outward, but this should not be used as the solution for equalizing pressure, a fan or grille should also be present.

X.T: Magnet room equipment and furnishings: The ultimate caveat emptor

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It is difficult to check the MR safetiness of everything in the room (e.g. a wooden chair with a metal frame), especially when the term "MR safe" changes of meaning.

X.T: FDA learns of more cases of gadolinium-related disease

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some MRI contrast agents have adverse effect on patients with kidney failures.

X.T: What your vendor may not have told you about magnetic contamination

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After having contained a MR for several years, a room may become improper for other use due to a permanent magnetization of its structure.

X.T: HIPAA compliance strategies for MR control rooms

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Most MR rooms are not HIPAA compliant, the authors suggest some ideas to solve this.

X.T: Part I: 10 questions to ask your architect about MRI suite design

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A quizz to test MR room designer wanabes…

X.T: Part II: Answers to the 10 questions to ask your architect about MRI suite design

ARTICLE.COMMENT: … and the answers.

X.T: Burying MRI construction mistakes: What you cannot see affects what you can

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some pitfalls to avoid.

X.T: Digital radiography slowly, but surely, makes its mark

ARTICLE.COMMENT: DR market share is increasing, but its price limits its growth despite the increased throughput. CR is cheaper and more adequate for immobile patients.

X.T: Implementing Digital - DR vs. DR

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This article presents the current state for DR products and indicates that it is probably too early to compare them.

X.T: Medical radiation workers see reduction in cancer risk

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Radiologists before 1950 were suffering from higher cancer rates than the remainder of the physicians.

X.T: Study compares eight digital x-ray systems in clinical setting

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A simple study comparing some systems using different technologies.

X.T: Digital hand atlas throws up puzzling results versus G&P atlas

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using XRay to perform bone age assessment.

X.T: 'Instant replay' fluoroscopy cuts radiation dose in children

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very basic idea: replay the last fluoro sequence instead of performing a new one helps to reduce radiation. I can't understand why this is a breakthrough.

X.T: Dual-energy digital x-ray still looking for acceptance

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of advantages of using dual-energy CR/DR.

X.T: New paper updates guidelines on fluoro radiation injuries

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A new article describes how to detect skin injuries due to fluoroscopy.

X.T: Breast Imaging Reporting and Data® Atlas (BI-RADS®) Atlas

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This is the official text. The Guidance Chapter is a very good way to understand the workflow in hospitals using BI-RADS.

X.T: A road map for integrating FFDM with generalized PACS

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A radiologist describes his experience with Fisher (acquisition + review) and DR System PACS. "radiologist productivity was halved", I am not sure this is a success… most sites would simply refuse this.

X.T: When push comes to shove: Addressing compression in mammography

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Even if women's complaint about breast compression is mainly the translation of their anxiety about cancer, some techniques can be used to reduce the discomfort.

X.T: Breast CT developers aim to 'revolutionize' mammography

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some researchers have created a special kind of horizontal CT scanner for mammo.

X.T: Expanded role looms for 3D in breast imaging

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of the technologies that may be used in future mammography.

X.T: How the legal system stacks the deck against mammography

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Mammography is bogged down by the number of malpractice lawsuits, and these ones have fully incompetent juries.

X.T: The parallax view: Digital breast tomosynthesis has cancer screening in its crosshairs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overly emphatic description of mammo tomosynthesis. It is true that this is very probably the future or mammography, but this article contains too much hype, it is not neutral in anyway.

X.T: DBT unlikely to hit its target as savior of breast cancer screening

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author claims that FFDM and DBT are dead end: "The future of breast cancer diagnosis lies in imaging function, not morphology".

X.T: Breast centers can manage malpractice risk

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice for breast imaging centers in order to protect themselves of lawsuits: document.

X.T: SNM: 1 year later, Mo-99 shortage 'a lot worse'

ARTICLE.COMMENT: US physicians are complaining that Canada still does not deliver Mo-99.

X.T: The Story of SPECT

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The current status of SPECT.

X.T: PET Project

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The current trends in PET imaging: CT/PET fusion, mammography…

X.T: PET/CT Basics

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A PET/CT tutorial for radiologists.

X.T: Investment firm garners third ultrasound THI patent, approaches vendors about licensing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information about Research Corporation Technologies, the companies owning the THI patents.

X.T: Microbubble contrast shows broad potential for US

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A californian laboratory is studying shelled microbubbles as a contrast agent. They can event push them, make them explode…

X.T: Requirements for continued advancement of 3D applications

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic requirements for visualisation: performance, correct models, registration, and ergonomics.

X.T: 3D labs add value for radiology

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Radiologists are now expected to provide 3D images.

X.T: Caution: Computers at Work

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some new companies, in particular R2, are proposing CAD tools.

X.T: What's Hot (and What's Not)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Cardiac, CAD, PACS and GE are the 2002 hot stuff.

X.T: Buying CAD: Worth a Second Look

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The current state of CAD: mammography, lung and colonoscopy.

X.T: Part I: Exploring PACS secrets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to choose a PACS: kind of RFP, real cost, choice of the service…

X.T: Part II: Exploring PACS secrets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Who owns the PACS and what factors should be taken into account for the ROI evaluation.

X.T: Part III: Exploring PACS secrets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Is it necessary to get help from a PACS consultant and, if yes, how to choose and work with him?

X.T: Part IV: Exploring PACS secrets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice to have an effective RSNA visit. The comments about engineers are funny, but quite true…

X.T: Part V: Exploring PACS secrets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A politically incorrect description of the PACS vendor world and of the buyer errors. Very good!

X.T: Part VI: Exploring PACS secrets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The current markey size, the evolution to software only deals, hospitals' RFP are still not good…

X.T: Part VII: Exploring PACS secrets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: About the importance to get the right information before deciding… A questionnaire is proposed.

X.T: Part VIII: Exploring PACS Secrets: It's broke

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Nothing new in this article, Cannavo tells us once more about customers who don't know how to properly define their needs and PACS vendors who do not teach them.

X.T: Part IX: Exploring PACS Secrets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The standards (DIOM, IHE) shall be mandatory instead of being optional.

X.T: Part X: Exploring PACS Secrets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: As always, the author explains, first, that imaging centers should go for a PACS, even with the new Deficit Reduction Act. Then, he says that price is not the main choice criteria. There is nothing new in this article…

X.T: Conversion algorithm eases PACS data migration

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using a RIS/PACS matching algorithm to migrate from an old PACS to a new one.

BLIST.TITLE: Reviewing images on a mobile phone

X.T: Mobile phones show promise for remote image viewing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Are they kinding?

X.T: Smartphone vs. PACS: Smartphone does just fine for skeletal trauma

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It seems that reviewing image on a phone becomes a reality. A very small study shows that using an Iphone is adequate.

X.T: MiniPACS eases CT data crunch

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A two tiers PACS architecture to handle the overload of CT data: a usual PACS to record all the reformated thick slices and the 3D snapshots and a mini-PACS to store all the original CT slices.

X.T: PACS users wise to maintain DICOM object integrity

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic advice about PACS use: keep private fields, avoid proprietary compression encodings…

X.T: PACS installations stuck in traffic jam

ARTICLE.COMMENT: 13 months are necessary, in average, between the decision of getting a PACS and having it installed.

X.T: Biological 'fingerprints' help identify mislabeled chest x-rays

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Misfiling of images on a PACS can be detected and corrected by using algorithms fingerprinting some anatomy parts..

X.T: European studies show SR has multilingual muscle

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Speech recognition reduces the time to transcript, review and sign the report.

X.T: Voice recognition speeds operations, irks radiologists

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A study about an implementation of voice recognition: it increased productivity, but annoyed the radiologist. But the article does not say what system (PACS vendor, VR software…) was used and does not analyze the data.

X.T: X-ray alien head vanishes from duck stomach

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A duck eats an alien…

X.T: X-ray reveals python's too-hot dinner

ARTICLE.COMMENT: … and a python eats an electric blanket.

X.T: Imaging reveals truth about Barnum mummy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A CT exam reveals that the Barnum mummy is a real one, not a hoax.

X.T: New CT scans of Pa-Ib mummy unveil more secrets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A new scan of the mummy gives further details.

X.T: Massachusetts bill takes aim at physician self-referral

ARTICLE.COMMENT: More and more US states define laws to control self-referral radiology examination.

X.T: Illinois AG dishes dirt on 'sham' MRI leasing deals

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some imaging centres pay illegal kickbacks to referring physicians.

X.T: Advancing the State of Data Integration in Healthcare

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This article gives the current status of the computerized patient record and proposes some success factors to have a real data integration accross the hospital.

X.T: Tongue and shriek: Piercing makes for unique imaging challenges

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Two problems with piercing: first, it is sometimes the cause of bad complications; second, it is an issue when acquiring images.

X.T: Thrall cites risks of outsourcing in RSNA opener

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some hospitals start to look at outsourcing radiology readings, but Thrall does not think globalization will happen.

X.T: Tomorrow's operating room to harness Net, RFID

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Unifying all the patient medical information on a single display and using RFID to recognize the hospital staff and the patients.

X.T: Open-source software delivers 3-way (PET/CT/MR) image fusion

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A CT/MR/PET fusion based on Osirix.

X.T: De nouvelles images en 3D des squelettes humains

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some news about Biospace Instruments, the company which tries to exploit Georges Charpak's discoveries.

X.T: FDA clearance for world's first RFID Surgical Sponge Counting System to prevent retention of surgical sponges

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using RFID to avoid sponges forgotten in the patient during surgery.

X.T: X-ray film market still growing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: For many years, I have heard that less and less films were produced. This seems to be globally wrong…

X.T: Lossy compression perceptible at even low levels

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A study on impact of image compression, but its protocol is far from a clinical workflow: comparing the images in flicker mode is much more stringent than performing a real exam reading.

X.T: Web site solicits patients for cases of radiology errors

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A web site collecting misdiagnosis reports is managed by a radiology services company.

X.T: Global Image Search

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Medting, a web site to share clinical images.

X.T: Canadian authorities review 70,000 cases after rad is suspended

ARTICLE.COMMENT: 5 years of a dubious radiologist have to be interpreted once again.

X.T: French government mulls nationwide PACS initiative

ARTICLE.COMMENT: France is studying the creation of regional PACS and a national long-term archive.

X.T: JFR: France shifts to regional focus for PACS deployment

ARTICLE.COMMENT: France will create four regional imaging PACS.
